I'm not a math major.  The trigonometry and differential calculus I studied in college is all wiped clean from my head.  However, I do have a head for math.  I can solve most simple equations in my head.  I can't really prove it, but I just tested myself out by doing 688+345 and 791*45 (first one was pretty quick, second one took a minute).  That doesn't really help when you need to calculate a dozen lines factored into even more combinations.  Things already got dicey after six puzzles, and I was trying to find a that would help me not have to try every combination of positive and negative numbers that adds up to 6, and once you’ve got an imbalance in one or two lines, you can’t tell if you have something wrong somewhere else unless you exhaust your options swapping out values.  It’s so frustrating when you’ve almost got it, but no matter how you tweak it, you can’t grab the value you need.  You just can't use simple logic, you need some kind of system if you don't want to spend an hour plugging in different numbers on the same puzzle.

I got a helpful pointer from a guide to add the smaller lines first and focus on those to model each puzzle, but it wasn’t helping that much.  Then I realized something: there’s already a natural imbalance in the sums of the lines and their components, because every component that’s on an intersection between lines is counted twice.  This means the sum of those spaces must be the difference between the sum of the lines and the sum of all components, or L – C = S!  Excited by this discovery, I immediately sought to capitalize on it.  It didn’t help.  I didn’t get anything plugging random values equal to S, and it just meant more tedious calculations to find L, C, and S, then double checking them on the board.  

This game needed more indicators or tools for finding solutions and fewer cutscenes with reject Stellaris species, though I will be fair and point out that the cutscenes are skippable: spacebar to reveal the skip button + click it on the top right.  I am genuinely curious if anyone has a good system for solving these, because none of the guides or reviews I’ve read actually describe one.  The testimonials mention rerolling the boards, notetaking, and brute-force guesswork.  I’ve tried all of that, it hasn’t usually helped, and it doesn’t feel that rewarding when it does.  The next step after that, according to the forums and reviews, is to program an autosolver or download one from Github.  These don’t sound like solutions to a game with well-balanced difficulty.
